results.title: Language of drawing
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Mechanical Drawing”.
This film attempts to provide a sensible and acceptable answer to the question: “Why study mechanical drawing?” and to stimulate the beginning of students’ interest in the subject.

results.title: Language of design
results.brief_description: Illustrates how Australian textile designers are finding inspiration from the local scene. Samples of sea shells, driftwood, dead twigs from a tea-tree, and other such mateerials collected on the Australian beach, are used in the studio to provide motifs for typically Australian textile designs. A series of such designs are effectively displayed by artistically draped samples.

results.title: Language development in multicultural classroom: science
results.creator_credit: Lisa Milner and Sydney College of Advanced Education
results.brief_description: Focuses on how to develop specific language related to science for English as a second Language students. It shows how grade 3 and 4 explored a theme around a unit on Space, providing the viewers with both strategies and practical ideas.

results.title: Language development (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Developmental psychology today”.
Shows the most current research being done on language development, such as Dr David Premack’s work at the University of California teaching language to chimpanzees. Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary levels.

results.title: Language development
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Human development: the first 2 1/2 years”.
This episode looks at how young infants acquire language. Chomsky’s theories about innate language competencies are examined as are the theories of operative conditioning and modelling where environment rather than herditary factors are seen to be more influential in the process of language acquisition. Babies use talking movements from birth and the program illustrates the processes whereby “babbling” becomes articulate speech.

results.creator_credit: David Seligman, BBC-TV, Open University and Caroline Pick

Notes the responses of two groups of tertiary students to a piece of literature and emphasises the importance of discussion in the formulation of ideas and problem solving.
Suitable for tertiary levels.

results.title: Language and communication
results.creator_credit: Ira R. Abrams, Harry Ratner, Holt, Rinehart and Winston and Coast Community College District
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Faces of culture”.
Across the earth can be heard the lilt and cadence of different languages. Each language is a framework for our feelings, our dreams and our wishes. Between three and five thousand languages are known to exist in the world today. Language is the primary vehicle through which culture is shared and transmitted and it is through language that we learn our culture. Various experts speak on this subject. Comparisons are made with the animal world. Touches on basic semantics, body language, and ritual codes. Also includes an interesting discussion on African-American dialect. Narrated by David Carradine.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ira R. Abrams, Harry Ratner, Holt, Rinehart and Winston and Coast Community College District

results.title: Language (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Glen Howard, State Film Productions and Harper & Row
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Development of the Child”.
Examines the child’s language process in the first four years, beginning with the development of phonemes, semantics and syntax. Looks at the process by which language is acquired and how that acquisition can be influenced.
